item.description: This card game from the 1920s has a picture of a beaver named "Bonzo" on the box, but this character is not one of the animals in the game! The 52 cards of the game include 13 sets of 4. There is a 53rd card used for scoring purposes only. All of the artwork is by G E Studdy, who's most famous creation was "Bonzo."

Kyoto Shogi is a Shogi variant played with specialized pieces on a 5x5 board. Its most unusual feature is that every move ends by "promoting" (flipping) the piece moved.

The pieces in Kyoto Shogi are non-standard pairings of standard Shogi units:

 Tokin / Lance
 Silver General / Bishop
 King
 Gold General / Knight
 Pawn / Rook




Rules for dropping are the same as in the closely related game, Microshogi.

name.value: Chester Gump Hops Over the Pole

item.description: Chester Gump Hops Over the Pole is a spin and move game by Milton Bradley. The object is to get from Washington to Moscow by encountering and overcoming obstacles and detours along the way.

The object of this card game is to be the first player to crown the queen. This is accomplished by laying down cards to form the queen's procession.

Each player is dealt three cards and the remainder of the pack is placed face downwards in the centre of the table. Players look at their cards and the one on the left of the dealer takes the top card from the centre pack. He then sees if he has a police-card in his hand. If so he can start the preparations for his procession immediately by laying this card on the table in front of him, face upwards. Each player makes his own procession. There are eight cards in a complete procession. If he has no police-card he passes one card, face downwards, to the next player.
If he has been able to play a police-card he takes another card from the centre pack and, if able, plays a FORCES card on to his procession and so on. When unable to add to his procession he passes any one card, face downwards, to the next player, leaving himself with three cards as at first.
Cards must be placed in a line in the following order: policeman, 3 different forces cards in any order (soldier, sailor, airman), royal coach, page, archbishop, and queen. Each processional card placed in front of a player scores 10 points and the queen-card scores 30 points, giving a maximum of 100 points per game.

A game is completed when one player has presented the Queen for crowning or the last card of the centre pack has been taken.

There are 54 cards in the deck:
7 x Policeman cards
5 x Soldier cards
5 x Sailor cards
5 x Airman cards
5 x Royal Coach cards
5 x Page cards
4 x Archbishop cards
4 x Queen cards
14 useless cards (1 each of Trumpeter, Royal Arms, Buckingham Palace, Houses of Parliament, Big Ben, Marble Arch, Hyde Park, Union Jack, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, India, Ceylon.)

This 1960's card game comes with 44 cards depicting family pets. There are several different types of pets and each card has a number as well as an animal on it.

The object of the game is to be the first to get rid of your cards by playing a card with either the same animal or the same number on it as the last card played. The number of cards you start with depends on the number of players. Every turn you try to play a card. If you cannot, you must draw a card instead. Once a player goes out, a hand ends and the remaining players must add up the point values left in their hands.

After 6 rounds, the player with the lowest score is declared the winner.

A card game for little children based on the Faraway Tree books by Enid Blyton. Consists of 44 cards featuring characters familiar to fans of the books. The object of the game is be the first to complete the story of The Faraway Tree by playing cards numbered 1 through 9. There are penalty cards to play against your opponents to try and slow them down.

item.description:
A card game with 44 animal cards divided into 7 sets. Each set has a "Mother" card, 1 or more "young" cards, 1 or more "Where Found" cards, and 1 or more "breed" cards. The cards of each set have the same number on them. This number is the points you earn by collecting that particular set.

The object of each round is to collect 1 "Mother", 1 "young", 1 "breed", and 1 "Where Found" card from any given set. The first player to do this wins any given round and receives the points shown on that set.

The fun part for little children comes in when a player has managed to collect a "Mother", a "breed" and a "where found" card for one set. At this point that player "cries" for the young by making the sound of that animal. The idea here is that the mother of the set is calling out for her young. When this happens, any player in possession of "young" cards of that specific animal type must give them to the crying player.

The first player to 60 points wins the game.

Players move celluloid cats and dogs around the board by spinning a spinner. The first one to the finish is the winner.

Parts:
2 celluloid Cats
2 celluloid Dogs
1 spinner with a cat on it
1 game board

The Base Ball Card Game, designed by the Allegheny Card Company, is an unpublished prototype boxed card game. The prototype contained 112 cards featuring 104 players with an additional eight team "ball counter" cards. There is exactly one original copy of the game, discovered in the 1980s, and it has since had the cards auctioned separately by Lew Lipset in April of 2000. There seem to have been a set of rules found with the prototype, but what became of them after the components were split up is unknown.

The game was registered on April 5th, 1904. It was never published.

"In 1904, the Allegheny Card Co. produced a 112 card boxed set including 104 National League players and 8 team “ball counter” cards. This issue is believed to be the “sole” produced prototype, having never been distributed to the general public."

Zombie racing! Just saying it causes you to say "What the…" When some were saying "Why?" Jim Bob Joe was saying "Why not?"

Civilizations have always been judged by their sports. Since before the gladiatorial contests in ancient Rome, man has been defined by his sport of choice.

Zombie racing. What more can you say?

Dead Heat is competitive on two levels. Not only can players race the Zeds, they can bet on them too! But wait, there's more!

Marvel (laugh your butt off) as highly trained Zombies (the fresher the better) streak down the track (OK, shuffle) in their quest for the gold (dinner). But these finely tuned athletes (hungry) aren't alone. Each Zombie is assisted by a loyal trainer (baiter) who desires only to share in their triumph (make a buck) all in the name of glory (because they have no other marketable skills).
Zombie racing… the name says it all!

Biscuit is a Decktet game for 2 to 4 players.

Object of the game: To score points by placing cards.

Setup: Deal each player six cards. Deal one card face down in the middle of the table and another card face up crossways on top of it. The remaining cards form the draw pile.

The player to the left of the dealer takes the first turn.

On your turn, you choose one card from your hand and place extend one of the lines of cards. The card you play must match at least one suit with the card adjacent to it in line.

The first player will place a card to the left or right of the initial card. Subsequent players may place cards on the left or right side of this main line. Later in the game, there may be cross lines that allow cards to be played up or down.

If you do not have a card that can be legally played, then you must draw a card. You may play it immediately if possible. Then it is the next players' turn.

If there are no cards left in the draw pile when a player is supposed to draw, the player does not draw and play continues.

Quincunx is a Decktet game for 2 to 4 players (with a solitaire variant).

The game is played on a five by five grid. On your turn, you add one card to the spread, score points depending on the connections between the played card and nearby cards, and possibly draw cards depending on those connections. You are penalized for any cards left in your hand at the end of the game.

Window is a Decktet solitaire game.

Object of the game: To merge all of the cards into a single pile.

Setup: Deal out nine cards face down, in a three by three grid. Deal nine more cards face down on top of those. Do it again, so that you have nine stacks of three cards each. Finally, deal one card face up onto each of the stacks.

Play: Move the cards around in certain ways to get all the cards into 2 pile to win.

Game Rules:
Window at the Decktet website

Bharg is a Decktet set-making game for 2 players.

Object of the game: To bind all the cards in your hand.

Setup: Each player is dealt a hand of seven cards. The dealer then deals one card face up to start a discard pile.

As the game progresses, there will be two discard piles: one for aces, the other for number cards and crowns. The discard pile for aces is called the Ace Pile.

Game play: On your turn, you may take the top card of the numbers-and-crowns discard pile or the top card of the deck. Then you discard a card.

item.description: In this soccer card game the cards represent which player controls the ball and black arrows show where he can pass or shoot. The same cards also can be used for defense as red arrows show which players can tackle the ball controlling player.

 Each player has an individual board on which their pawn moves from Salvation at game start to Future Things at game end. To advance one's pawn along this journey, players must answer Biblical questions in the categories of Prayer, Bible Study, Fellowship, Witnessing, Doctrine, and Promises.

item.description:
Each player has 25 equilateral triangles in his color. After the first tile, players alternate playing a tile adjacent to some existing tile.

The winner is the first player to form a larger, 4-tile triangle with his color on the tips, and either color in the center.

Online Play

 boardspace.net Real time, AI option
 gamerz.net (play by email)

item.description:
TRIANGLES :

Players buy 3 and 4 spaces triangles from the 36 spaces triangle of the board. In that order, they bid simultaneously and secretly for a pair of triangles on the board. When the bids are revealed, the winner of the auction marks the two acquired spaces with triangles of his colour, and gets points of reward. He then elects two new spaces on the board for sale. 
Every three rounds, all players receive 100 extra points for bidding. 
The Board has special areas showing the capital and scores of each player.
Typical race game for children with very cute cars and easy rules. Contents two different boards.

item.description:
Components:
-16 playing cards. Use all of the face cards and aces from a standard deck of poker cards.
-two uniquely colored pawns, one for each player.
-4x4 playing board

Win by guessing the location of your opponent’s treasure before they find yours.

Set a Trap & Hide your Treasure.
On a player’s turn they must move their pawn and they may optionally make one guess as to where their opponent’s treasure is hidden. To move a player plays one card and moves their pawn to a space in the row (or column) which is labeled with that card.

http://www.superpowernosissies.com/games/

Board has a turning disk under it to place the treasure chest in 1 of 16 holes on board, each covered with a gold coin.

Players are pirates looking to be the first to collect 25 coins. Movement is by rolling two six sided dice. Rolling doubles gives you the option to add another of your playing pieces to the board.

When you reach a hole on the board, collect the coin and check to see what's under it. The treasure chest is worth 10 coins, you can also find nothing, or be captured by another player and sent to their hideout. To be released takes one coin and a roll of doubles, or two coins without the roll.

First player with 25 coin wins.

Play many classics, updated for the third millennium by adding a third dimension to card games. This deck has 5 numbers, 5 colors, and 5 suits. Each card contains 1 number, 1 color, and one suit, making 125 cards, 1 for each number/color/suit combination.

This deck can play many games. (14 are currently published at with more to come when I sell 100 decks.) But all games take advantage of the fact that it's a 3 dimensional card. Play 3D versions of Crazy Eights, Memory, Spite and Malice, Speed, Poker, Rummy, Blackjack, Cassino, Euchre, Tic Tac Toe, and 2 different versions of Klondike Solitaire. Plus there's 2 games which cannot be duplicated with regular cards.

One is a 3-variable trick-taking game where you want to take certain cards but not others,Circles are worth positive points, but are the least powerful suit, and squares are negative points but the most powerful suit in terms of trick taking. But Number rank and color team declarations take precedence over suit. Can be played cooperatively, 2 on 2, or 4 for themselves. Most net positive points wins.

The other game is an elimination card game where the object is to give someone six of the same number, color, or suit to eliminate them, and to be the last one standing. Blacks, Blobs, and Question Marks always bring its owner closer to elimination. And you can play offensively on your opponents cards, or defensively to make it harder to eliminate you. A near perfect chess match with cards for 2 players, a game of negotiations if played with more.

Coming soon: 3D versions of 2 competitive solitaires, Thirty-One, Go Fish, 2 Versions of Egyptian War, another version of Spite and Malice, another version of Speed, Pope Joan, and Eleusis.

item.description:
Hex is an abstract strategy game for 2, 3, 4, or 6 players played on a symmetric board of 54 hexagonal spaces. Team play is possible. Each player starts with 6 plain ceramic hexagonal pieces, including 5 hexmen and 1 (taller) hexcellency which starts on his hexdom space. The winner is the player who either first moves his hexcellency to the hexdom on the opposite side of the board or whose hexcellency is the last hexcellency remaining on the board. A piece must move in a straight line not blocked by other pieces. A piece may be immobilized ("hexed") or released from a hex by certain configurations of other pieces. On a later move, a hexed piece may be removed ("captured") from the game. A player is eliminated from the game if his hexcellency is captured.

From the game box top: "the Cerulean Hexman moved swiftly into position and engaged his hexray. The Citronian was instantly hexed. Powerless and immobile, he unwillingly released the Alizarian Hexman form his certain fate. He again activated his hexray. The Citronian Hexcellence was paralyzed, ensnared hopelessly, just as victory was within his reach. His Hexdom had been conquered…"

Hex was published in 1994 as a "limited First Edition" of one thousand copies. It did not include actual hexrays.

Battlestar Galactica: il gioco da tavolo
Battlestar Galactica: Le Jeu de Plateau
太空堡垒 卡拉狄加

item.description:
Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game is an exciting game of mistrust, intrigue, and the struggle for survival. Based on the epic and widely-acclaimed Sci Fi Channel series, Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game puts players in the role of one of ten of their favorite characters from the show. Each playable character has their own abilities and weaknesses, and must all work together in order for humanity to have any hope of survival. However, one or more players in every game secretly side with the Cylons. Players must attempt to expose the traitor while fuel shortages, food contaminations, and political unrest threatens to tear the fleet apart.

After the Cylon attack on the Colonies, the battered remnants of the human race are on the run, constantly searching for the next signpost on the road to Earth. They face the threat of Cylon attack from without, and treachery and crisis from within. Humanity must work together if they are to have any hope of survival…but how can they, when any of them may, in fact, be a Cylon agent?

Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game is a semi-cooperative game for 3-6 players ages 10 and up that can be played in 2-3 hours. Players choose from pilots, political leaders, military leaders, or engineers to crew Galactica. They are also dealt a loyalty card at the start of the game to determine if they are a human or Cylon along with an assortment of skill cards based on their characters abilities. Players then can move and take actions either on Galactica, on Colonial 1, or in a Viper. They need to collect skill cards, fend off Cylon ships, and keep Galactica and the fleet jumping. Each turn also brings a Crisis Card, various tasks that players must overcome. Players need to play matching skill cards to fend off the problems; skill cards that don't match hinder the players success. Fate could be working against the crew, or there could be a traitorous Cylon! As players get closer and closer towards reaching their Earth, another round of loyalty cards are passed out and more Cylons may turn up. If players can keep their up their food stores, fuel levels, ship morale, and population, and they can keep Galactica in one piece long enough to make it to Earth, the Humans win the game. But if the Cylon players reveal themselves at the right moment and bring down Galactica, the Humans have lost.

Official Site, Rules & FAQ: http://www.fantasyflightgames.com/edge_minisite_sec.asp?eidm=18&esem=4
Unofficial FAQ for really tricky questions: http://boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/Battlestar_Galactica_FAQ

item.description:
From the instructions:

"Bocaro....it's fun, fast and easy to play! Trying to get 12 strikes in a row for a perfect 300 game makes Bocaro exciting.....every time you play."

Bocaro is played and scored just like the sport of bowling.

Each player may turn over (roll) two cards in each frame, trying for a count of 10. If the first card is a strike you don't need to roll another card. If the second card is needed and gives you a combined count of more than 10, you only count 10 for a spare.

"Almost all new wargamers start their careers by fighting a succession of single, unconnected battles;...but before very long he begins to feel that something is lacking, that these individual games...need some connecting link to make them more satisfying and to give an objective other than just trying to destroy the other fellow's army. In their words, the desire to fight campaigns rather than battles." ( From the authors introduction)

A practical book on setting up a miniatures campaign for a variety of eras stretching from ancient times to WW2, with chapters on map making & movement, contacts and battles, umpired games, supply and finance, creating worlds and characters, campaign newspapers, political skull drudgery, with full rules for the authors Hyborian Campaign set in the world of Robert E. Howards' Conan the Barbarian.

Soft cover publication. 76 pages, with one illustration and numerous tables.

This is an absorbing game where players strategically place their pawns upon a circular playing board where placing holes are joined by a web of lines. Depending upon where pegs are placed, depends much on where a player already has pegs in that line of direction, because, on their subsequent turn on placing another peg in that same line will then be able to 'expel' the opponent's peg from the board! The web of lines and number of pegs in play at any one time helps confuse issues that inevitably leads to increased concentration, and the players subsequently taking the game far more seriously!

This is a game similar to Roulette, but uses more than one ball, and one of those is worth 'double' of wherever it lands. It's pure luck of course, but despite its simplicity, becomes quite addictive and is a lot of fun to play!

Decoder is so quick that you should think of it as a "warm up" game rather than a game to entertain you for a whole evening. It's simple to play, quick to explain and is a good ice breaker to get everyone into a 'gamesy' mood.

The game includes fifteen images and the idea of the game is to guess the phrase depicted by the image.

Free game here: http://www.amherstlodge.com/dirtycheats/fbg/downloads/games/decoder.htm

In Pack & Stack the players try to fill their trucks as perfectly as possible.

Players start each round with a random selection of different-sized goods, determine by the roll of several dice. Then each player takes one or two trucks from the supply face-down (numbers depend on the number of players) The trucks are revealed simultaneously and each player tries to make a quick assessment to get the truck that is most useful for his or her supply of goods. Players stack the goods in the space of their selected truck defined by the boundaries on the truck-bed and the height restriction noted on the truck. Players get negative scores if the truck they picked was too large (a lot of unused space at 1 point per unused space) or too small (a lot of goods don't fit at 2 points per space of goods that would not fit). The player who gets the lowest negative score in a round gains 10 points. Players "pay" points for their negative values, and rounds continue until at least one player no longer has any points; the player with the most points wins.

item.description: Played by two and up to six people, each using a numbered disc to be found in the upper left hand corner. Any player can start this game. Each advances his disc the number of squares indicated on the spinner. Should the disc be advanced to a square with a double number (red and black), he/she is forced to move to the square indicated by the red number. If the disc falls into a square marked TRY IT AGAIN, player is allowed another spin. The player who is the first to reach the red square marked 92 or 93 is the winner.

Wratismania is an educational boardgame made by Polish artist. His purpose was to teach people about WrocÅ‚aw -- a Polish city, the capital of Lower Silesia. Players are moving on the map using three methods of communication: by bus, by taxi and on foot. By visiting various places they collect cards with brief description of place. The player who will get the most cards, wins.

Trivia game made by MB.
Similar to Trivial Pursuit (same questions categories), if a roll and move game on a solar system. You might to collect all the planets (like Mercury, Venus,...) and arrive to the end of the table.

Components:

252 Question Cards (quiz 2000 cards,general question)
200 Question Cards (planets cards)
6 Player piece
36 Planets Rings
1 Rule Book

From instructions:

"The Magnetic Game of Toggle Pins"

A game of skill and action wherein the player tries to pull his own color Toggle Pins into his "fenced-in" area by skillful manipulation of a magnet.

The bottom portion of the box is used as the playing platform and is first assembled into a raised platform by attaching 4 plastic legs. Each player sits at one side of the platform next to his or her "GOAL". Each player selects 20 Toggle Pins of the same color has their "GOAL" and places them in the center of the board. Each player then takes a magnet.

Magnets are rubbed under the playing surface to break up the pile of pins and guide them into their home goal. Each time a player draws a wrong colored pin into their own Goal, they must pick up that pin and one of their own and return both to the center enclosure.

It is the season of celebration and it all starts when the young men of the village compete to ring the bell for
the honor of their families and to signal the start the festival. This ancient competition requires strength,
stamina and teamwork. Players will take the roll of a team of climbers that must race to the top of the
temple to start the celebration; they are bound by strict rules and are rewarded for how high on the temple
they are able to climb.

Free Game from Here: http://www.pyromythgames.com/free_games.html

item.description:
A very simple game from PyroMyth Games. 1 page of rules, 1 page with the board and tiles on it. Each player receives 4 tiles. These tiles have arrows pointing different directions and a point value. After a player places a tile they score their points for that play. Points are totaled by adding the value of the tile plus the value of the board position or tile if it has been played on that every arrow on their tile points to.

Full Game: http://www.pyromythgames.com/offerings/freegames/freegames.html

The goal is to capture 4 Checkers of one color or 6 checkers total. Each player takes a turn moving one of the checkers on the outside ring of the board, and then moving the die which is in the center of the board.

Full Game: http://www.pyromythgames.com/offerings/freegames/opposition/opposition.html

item.description: Neptune uses 1-2 decks of regular playing cards. You also need a trident (search for a 3-tined fork) and the crown included. The Starting player plays some cards from his hand which must be all the same kind, but any number of them. The other players then in turn lay down cards which try to beat his. The winner takes all the cards. The Crown and the Trident are gained in special ways and have special powers for use during the game.

Object: To claim opponent’s cards by determining the number of a given card in their hand.

Every turn a card will be turned face up and each player will announce how many cards in their hand can be divided evenly into it. These cards should be put in separate piles by rank so everyone can see what has been draw through out the game. If a player has no cards that can be evenly divided into it they announce Indivisible.

Starting with the player with the coin and continuing clockwise each player may attempt (but is not required) to guess one other players cards. The need to tell what card they are looking for and how many that player has in their hand. Guessing 0 is not valid. If they are correct in guessing both the rank of the card and how many the guessing player gets that card/s and places them face up in front of them for scoring at the games end. If they are wrong they must discard one card from their hand face up onto the common piles. When a player has no more cards in their hand they may no longer guess and are out until scoring.

Full Rules: http://www.pyromythgames.com/offerings/freegames/indivisible/indivisible.html

To start the game place the dominoes face down and mix them well. Each player draws 5 tiles keeping the values hidden from the others. The youngest player should get to go first; play will continue clockwise. On a players turn they will take the following actions in order.

1. Draw a tile

2. Score a set of tiles if possible

3. Bring hand to 5 tiles

You score a set of tiles: Tiles are scored by matching a set of three or more so that the top row value is equal to the value of the bottom row.

Rules: http://www.pyromythgames.com/offerings/freegames/deadeven/deadeven.htm

Target is to put all of your pieces in enemy's places, trying to win most points while.

Game ends when one of the players do that, but the player who have more points will be the winner.

This game is a close relative of the Slimetrail game.

There are two players: red and blue snails. Initially snails are placed in the opposite corners of the rectangular board.

The snails can be moved to adjacent cells and may not move to a cell occupied by the opponent's snail or re-visit a visited cell.

The game ends up when one of the players cannot move his snail on his turn. The other player wins in this case.

Usually played with progressive-moves variant.

An educational card game consisting of 24 matching pairs of cards. Players take turns drawing from a pile of white cards on which is printed a scripture passage that tells an incident in the Bible. Green cards that describe the incident are held in the players' hands. If a card drawn can be matched with one of the player's green cards, the pair is set aside. The first player to match all his green cards wins the game.

The Open Numbers Game is a collection of several games based around the idea of moving numbered pieces on a board. Two different sets of numbered pieces are provided, the "large game" (numbered 0 up to 99, for use with a 10x10 board) and the "small game" (numbered 0 up to 31 twice over, for use with an 8x8 board).

The Open Word Game consists of several different games based around the idea of moving lettered pieces on an 8x8 board to form rules.

There are 64 pieces in the set: two copies of each consonant and four of each vowel (including Y). (Since the Russian alphabet has 33 letters, in the original Russian version there are two of each letter except Ðª and Ð¬ of which there are one each.) In addition each piece has a numeric score depending on the rarity of its letter, and a suit (red, yellow, green or blue).

Fast and funny game for kids.
Chose one tokens from the table, and collect the similar object. Don't pick up the tokens "PULCE"! You may discard all the tokens you collect!

From the collection MINIGAME of Editrice Giochi.

Time's Up Deluxe is the tenth anniversary edition of one of the most popular party games for gamers! This is a brand new edition, with the best of the cards from the base set and the two expansions (525 cards), a whole bunch of new cards, and best of all, a very handy new electronic timer.

Time's Up! is a party game for teams of two or more players (best with teams of two). The same set of famous names is used for each of three rounds. In each round, one member of a team tries to get his teammates to guess as many names as possible in 30 seconds. In round one, almost any kind of clue is allowed. In round two, no more than one word can be used in each clue (but unlimited sounds and gestures are permitted). In round three, no words are allowed at all.

Includes rules for an odd number of players as well as an optional fourth round.

name.value: There Must Be a Victory: Clash of Ironclads

item.description:
Sailing ships with broadsides - the last vestige of "wooden ships and iron men."

They mingle in a fleet action with iron-plated steamships, speedy armored rams, and a few ships with armored turrets.

Mobile Bay? Charleston?

No, it's the Adriatic, in a short and violent naval war between Italy and Austria-Hungary. Yes, you heard right. Finally, you'll have a chance to see the Austro-Hungarian navy in action. Historically, they did very well. How will you do?

The "Seven Weeks War" of 1866 is also known as the Third Italian Independence War. The Italians want Venice. The Austrians have it. But the Italians are allied with up-and-coming Prussia, and the Austrians have a hard time on land. On the Adriatic, the Austrio-Hungarian fleet is outnumbered and out gunned, more to 2-1 in both categories. But they have aggressive commanders and a willingness to "Ram anything painted grey!" That was the signal from the Austrio-Hungarian flagship (the Italians would be the folks with gray ships). The same signal included the sentence, "There must be a victory at Lissa."

And now it's up to you to find out if there will be, or if the Italians succeed in making the Adriatic "an Italian lake."

It is a classic confrontation, by designer Paul Rohrbaugh, of numbers versus quality, with over 200 multi-sized counters featuring individual ships and the admirals who commanded the fleets. Players maneuver on an operational map and then shift to smaller battle maps when it's time to put their iron to the test.

Two scenarios - just the conclusive Battle of Lissa or the entire campaign, along with important random events, intrusions by the French and Turks, optional rules for ships and events that could have happened, and more. Will you, as Italian Admiral Persano, see that the Austrian flag is "swept" from the Adriatic? Or will you, as Austrian Admiral Tegetthoff prove that your rams and unusual "flying wedge" formation can overcome superior firepower?

The choices are yours!

item.description:
1947 board game by Parker Brothers.

Object of Game: The object of the game is to become the first person to buy a house, furnish it and secure $1,000 additional for a savings account.

Game Parts:

A circular board with a spinning dial
2 dice
Bank containing road cash counters
4 receipt books and receipts
4 moving pieces
4 house cards
4 sets of house furnishings

Stock trading game.

Game has a wooden game board with stocks circling in a square on the top. Stocks are NYCRR, UPRR, SPRR, Grand Union, A and P, Woolworth, Pure, Shell, Socony, American Sugar, American Wool, American Tobacco, National Steel, Bethlehem Steel, US Steel, Sears Roebuck, Montgomery Ward, Chrysler, Ford, Packard, US Rubber, Firestone, Goodyear, Western Union, Postal, Swift, Armour, Wilson, Aviation and Curtis Wright.

The board has four corners which are: Market News, Today's Market, Market Quotations, Market at a Glance.

There is a spinner in the middle of the board and the board has holes the fit the wooden peg playing pieces.

Game Parts:

On the Board Chance Cards include options to buy stocks, lucky breaks, John Law, obstacles, Santa Claus, happy days.

Stock certificates for Bell, Dupont, Goldfield Mining, Hecla Mining, Montana Mining, Atlantic Oil, Standard Oil, Shell Oil, Erie Canal, White Star, General Motors, Chrysler, Studebaker, China Clipper, Yellow Cab, Greyhound.

Money in dollar amounts of $500, $1,000, $5,000, $10,000, $50,000 and $100,000 and a loans log.

Object of Game: At the end of play, which may be for a specified period of time, each player cashes in his Stock and Bond Certificates at their then listed current values, and the player who has made the greatest gain over the original amount of money with which play was begun will be declared the winner.

To parallel actual Stock activity 6% has been designed with fluctuations of Stock as one of its prime features.

Game Parts:
Game board with squares denoted stocks, bonds and other stock exchange terms
Bull, Bear and Revenue cards
Pair of dice
Current Value stock board 
Stock and Bond Certificates 
Paper money in $100, $1,000, $5,000 and $10,000
Plastic 6$ symbols
Margin and sell short chips

Object of Game: To see which of 4 errand boys can meet with the greatest success.

Players spin the spinner and move around the board landing on squares that direct them to success or failure. The winner is the first person to reach the "44" square.

Parts - 4 wooden pegs and one spinner. Instructions on back of box top. Brightly colored and lithographed board.

Pentaplane is a three-dimensional board (five stacked 5x5 square grids) on which several games can be played:


 Pentaplane-Aircraft. A "rudimentary" game (the designer's word) in which each player controls a single piece representing an airplane and attempts to shoot down the opponent. Moves are plotted in groups of five. The planes move the same as the rooks do in the later games.



 Pentaplane-Checkers. This is played much like standard checkers, but the pieces move diagonally between boards, not on the same board. Some spaces on the boards have dots to facilitate diagonal movement, which is always from dot to dot or blank to blank.



 Pentaplane-Chess. This has a number of differences from standard Chess besides the board. There are no kings of queens, instead there are monarchs, and they can only be obtained by promoting pawns. Pawns can move backwards as well as forwards. The bishops move the same way as the pieces in Pentaplane-Checkers.



 Super Pentaplane-Chess. Pentaplane-Chess but with a much greater variety of pieces: a president which can move along flat diagonals, a hopper which must jump over another piece when moving, missile versions of pieces which can destroy other pieces at a distance, bomb versions of pieces which can blow up and destroy a 3x3x3 area, etc. Players agree on which pieces are allowed before the game. They do not have to use the same set of pieces. Note that the new pieces introduced here are not included in the Pentaplane set.



 Pentaplane V. This game is not included in the rulebook, but is available online (see the Links section). This is a modified version of Super Pentaplane-Chess with some differences in the list of pieces.
Roll-and-move stock trading game. The rules suggest that players should be cutthroat.

The Who's Who Game is a game of naming famous people based on lettered dice rolls. Players take turns throwing dice and calling out a name with two initials on the dice. A successful name means moving a space. Players are limited in time to call out a successful name by a unique timer. The timer works by releasing a ball at the top of a ramp leading to a circular funnel type pit. It takes approximately 10 seconds for the ball to settle into the center pit. Players start with 4 dice and work down to 2 dice near the end of the board. A category die is also included when the players have advanced far enough on the board. First to the end wins.

Goals And Glory is a game about football, power and money.
In goals and glory you are a manager for your own danish football team, and your job is to handle the press and create economical success.
Mention that the other players also have the same thing in mind.

The players place their tokens on the start space.Each turn the players throw a die. If a 1 is thrown the player can move the pawn to the next field. When a player throws 2 - 5 the player takes a card from the pile. The player reads the question on the card aloud. The hourglass is turned and every player, including the player who had read the card, has 2 minutes to give the right answer. If a player knows the answer, he/she shouts 'stop.' When it is the correct answer that player may move its pawn to the next grey circle corresponding to the number on the card. Otherwise the player has to move backwards to the circle with the same number. If a 6 is thrown the player may choose a card from the pile.
When there is no time left and nobody has given the correct answer, then the next player starts its turn. The first player who reaches the last space, wins the game.

A variant of the game is to write down the answer and compare them when the time is up. All the players move their tokens forward or backwards.

Loose words
Knowledge of human nature
Nature and environment
Celebrities
Guess the profession
Knowing the world
Scribbling Stuff

Germany turned 50 in 1999 so thats a good reason to party!
1800 Questions (and Answers) from 1949 to 1999 are celebrating the History of East and West Germany.

name.value: Harry Potter und der Stein der Weisen Halloween

item.description: Two players reenact the scene from the movie "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" in which Harry and Wesley rescue Hermione from the Troll in the bathroom at Hogwarts.

Da Stimmt was Nicht! (Something is Wrong!) is an educational game based on the fairy tale "Snow White and the Seven Dwarves". The game includes a story book of the tale, and a set of cards that correspond to pages in the book. Players match the cards to the book pages and try to find the differences, and win one a wooden dwarf when they are the first to recognize the mistakes. A player wins when they collect two dwarves, but you can lose them too so the game as not as easy as it might sound! The components are excellent in the game as well.

"Unbridled Fury is a set of miniatures rules for the fantasy genre which is designed from the ground up for skirmish battles. These small engagements and affrays are set in worlds as diverse as the players themselves (as well as the history of our very own Earth). It has no ‘official’ setting or miniatures line and allows the players to use whatever they want, in whatever setting they desire."

"Game-play is fast and brutal. The game is a departure from the regular approach to fantasy skirmish games - combat feels more like an all-out brawl rather than organized groups of fighters rolling dice at each other. You can almost feel the pain of the fighters as they hurl themselves into battle. Once the players get a grip on the rules games are usually over in under an hour, which is crucial to those who have to squeeze real life in between them. Physical space required is also
small - most 4’ x 4’ terrain boards are ideal; kitchen tables will suffice, though, and may even produce a tighter battle."

The rules were designed to be used with 28mm figures. "[O]ne figure represents one warrior, beast or frothing lunatic, so the effect of a single figure on the game is of great importance."

"Every figure has a profile, a set of equipment (weapons, armour, etc.) and possibly some 'special abilities.'" The profile for a figure consists of nine categories plus any special abilities. Special abilities include Berserker, Camouflage, Creature of Darkness, Fanatic, Flier, Giantslayer, Invisible, Musician, Night Vision, Teleporter, Undead, and Were-Creature.

The game includes rules on creating characters, companies, and setting up games using scenario creation tables. The game play covers areas such as command, morale, visibility, ambushes, cowardice, and fires.

from the box front:
Mummbly
General Knowledge
A Game of Chance & Trivia

from the box back:
Roll the Dice,
Knock Down the Numbers,
Answer the Questions
& Score

from the manufacturer's website (www.mummbly.ca)
Mummbly Chance - This is a low score dice game that involves concealing a number or any one combination of numbers in the series according to the sum of the dice toss.
Mummbly Trivia - This is a high score trivia dice game that involves concealing a number or any one combination of numbers in the series according to the sum of the dice toss, and collecting valued trivia cards.

This game is very similar to Double Shutter. The game box starts with the numbers 1-9 flipped up. You roll two d6 and add them together. You then flip down enough numbers to add up to the total you rolled. Once you roll a number that can't be summed up by numbers still showing, you score by counting and summing these remaining numbers. This is the Mumbly Chance game. Mumbly Trivia adds Trivial Pursuit-like cards to the gameplay.

name.value: Rules for the conduct of the war-game on a map

item.description:
British Army version of Kriegsspiel rules written in 1896.

Designed to be played with one or more umpires and several players per side.

Differs from the Prussian 1824 Krieggspiel by having the combat resolved by the umpire's judgment instead of the 1824 version's dice and combat tables.

Includes very useful tables containing march rates and frontage distances for military units just prior to WWI.

War Office rules for a game published originally in 1896. The rules are the clearest statement of the British Army´s understanding of the tactical realities on the battlefield pre-World War I
They highlight:

 The dubious nature of bayonet charges
 The value of trenches
 The necessary for artillery to engage from beyond rifle range
 Rates of march
 etc.




The War Game is intended to afford a representation of military maneuvers. It is played on a map drawn to a large scale, the troops engaged being indicated by small metal blocks, coloured Red for one force, Blue for the other.

The game needs at least two players (one for Red and the other for Blue) and an Umpire, but can easily accommodate more players in either side or as the Umpire's Assistants. Also is suggested to have an officer who would describe the game in play for a later memorandum

item.description:
The Warhammer 40,000 Rulebook is the ultimate and essential guide to playing Warhammer 40,000 - In a savage future age, Mankind must battle for survival in a galaxy riven by destruction and bloodshed. Warhammer 40,000 is set in a time when power-armoured Space Marines and the uncountable numbers of the Imperial Guard must stand against the slavering hordes of alien warriors.

This 320-page hardback rulebook contains all the information you need to get started with Warhammer 40,000, including: full rules for fighting tabletop battles, a history of the 41st Millennium, a guide to the races and armies that can be found in the far future, and a hobby section on how to choose, collect and paint a Warhammer 40,000 army of Citadel miniatures and set-up a battlefield to fight over.

item.description:
Dial & Learn is an educational trivia game which uses a mechanical dialer to verify answers to common educational trivia questions. Categories include "The World of Science", "Lands and Seas", etc.

Recommended Ages 7 - 12

Contents:
Magic Dialer
Scorecards
Special marking pencil
Question cards
Rule Book

It's a game of mental agility and competition which objective is to accumulate the most points along the 20 rounds. 
Each round has two different games, the first one called "Prueba de vocabulario" (vocabulary test) in which players will have to find the longest word using 9 given letters. Players randomly draw letter tiles asking for either a vowel or a consonant, there are also some "joker" cards that can work as any letter. The second game is called "Prueba de cálculo" (math test) in which players will have to get as close as possible to a number generated randomly with 3 dices (number between 1 to 999) using for it just 6 numbers. Players randomly draw number tiles asking for either a unit (1-9) or a decimal (10-90).

Allows from 2 to 6 players (12 if played in teams).

name.value: Trivial Pursuit Édition Café Jacques Vabre

item.description:
Limited edition of Trivial Pursuit for the French coffee brand Jacques Vabre.
Contains
1 board
1 dice
6 round meepled
36 colored triangles (to fit into the meeples)
396 cards with questions

Categories:
blue: production
pink: coffee tasting
yellow: history and legends of coffee
brown: the brand Jacques Vabre
green: coffee producing countries
orange: green coffee

The rules are similar to the classical Trivial Pursuit.
The question are all coffee related and quite difficult.
This game was never sold in shops but distributed by the coffee brand for promotion.

At the beginning of the play each player specifies purposes in life for itself its, in whom he distributes at least 250 points on the different columns (social, career, luck, education and wealth). This is valid to reach it now in the play. Each player can contain questions, have their answer different effects to the markers of the purposes in life or also simple instructions to shift the markers. Some fields of the programme are barriers, which only to be overcome to be able, if appropriate values were reached with certain purposes in life. Who met its targets at the best one, the play wins.

Multimatch I and II deals with square tiles, while Multimatch III and IV concerns triangular tiles. 
The box of Multimatch III contains a plastic hexagonal trail, and an acrylic set of MacMahon's Four-Color triangles. All 24 triangles are divided into three equal triangles (with short edges joining the centre to the corners) coloured with 4 colors.
The 1991 edition Kadon rulebook contains a large section of puzzles, and rules for 3 games, plus variants.

The games are:
Multimatch. Players take turns placing tiles on the hexagonal trail. The first piece placed on a border of the board determines the color of that border. Last player wins.
Outmatched. Players divide the tiles equally (face-down) and then race to assemble their group into a symmetrical shape, with tile edges matching.
Closure. The tiles are assembled into a random (but edge-matching) group. Players take turns "closing" one of the 3 colors by moving as few tiles as possible. Closing a color requires leaving no exposed edges of that color. Moves may not separate any tiles from the group.

The game of the 10 clues.
The players must guess the secret word on the card with as few clues as possible, the fewer number of clues needed to guess the word the more spaces your team can move. The board consists in a track, the first player or team on go around for ten times wins the game.

Components:
- 500 cards
- 1 board
- 12 player pieces

item.description:
"For anyone who has ever dreamed of being among the collectors and the collected... Of organizing the openings and celebrating the sales... Of starving artists in a garret for the sake of the muse... But be warned: in the game, as in life, it takes more than talent to win. Anyone can play Artist - but, it's only the right combination of cash, canvases, contacts, and conniving that will make you a success!"

The first edition states that it was limited to 2000 copies.

Components include a game board styled after an artist's palette, instructions, a pad of Resume Score Sheets, cards, play money, and plastic discs.

"New, Fascinating, Instructive. The Game of Africa, or Contest of the Search Expeditions."

"Three games in one. Any number can play. Amuses. Educates without study. Contains Expeditions, Playing-Board, Map, 64 Cards, comprising authentic biographies, history, geography. Sold by booksellers, etc., or sent, post paid, on receipt of price, $1.00."

name.value: Playing Gods: The Board Game of Divine Domination

item.description:
From the publisher:

Playing Gods is a satirical board game of divine domination. Two to five players each play a different god, and compete with each other to take over the world. This is done by spreading your believers, converting the followers of other gods, or killing them off with Acts of God.

Playing Gods also has an open-ended structure that encourages player creativity. For example, players may choose to be a figurehead of one of the five main religions, or they may choose to create their own gods – or even be their own god! In the Expansion Pack (sold separately), artistic and creative players may even write and design their own cards.

item.description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

In this version of Monopoly the goal is to organize the world

An antique word game played using five wooden cubes (dice) marked with letters. The other components include two wooden dice cups and a rules sheet. The game came in a colorful 7.5 x 4 x 2 inch box marked: "Fun for old and young. Exciting new letter game." And the instructions tout: "The most popular of all Letter Games."

Summum is an abstract strategy game for 2 persons. The players take turns placing pieces on the colorful board trying to form one of three patterns. Players have to decide whether to score points or prevent the opponent for scoring points.
When one of the three patterns is formed the player scores points based on the pattern and the color of the rectangle on which the last piece of the pattern is placed.
The game ends when both players played their last piece.
The kings on the side of the board keep track of the score.

Contents
36 white pieces
36 black pieces
2 kings
1 board
rules

For more infomation visit: http://www.magi-games.nl/sum/index_sum.html (Dutch)

item.description: This is a simple shoot and hit the target type of game from Cadaco Ellis that was produced in 1948.

"The New Game of Which Is It? Bird, Beast, or Fish? Speak Quick or Pay."

An antique card game consisting of a deck of 52 cards colorfully depicting a variety of birds, fish, and other animals. Each card is marked with a number (5, 10, 15, or 20, and one 50.) The 50 point card is "Mr. Crowley", described in the rules as the famous Chimpanzee who for many years delighted children at the New Your City Zoo in Central Park.

There are two game variations. The game play revolves around playing a card when its name as read from a story in the rulebook. Points are scored according to the numbers on the cards.

Card manifest: 18 bird cards, 16 fish cards, 18 cards with other animals. The game also included a box and a rules booklet.

This game is essentially a roll-and-move race game for 2 to 4 players, but instead of using dice, a series of tiles with movement numbers are drawn from a face-down pile. The board illustrates events in the story of Little Red Bushy Tail, a popular children;s story of the time.

Contents:

Board
Draw Tiles
4 player pieces
Instruction Booklet

"As Interesting as Radio Itself. Rules For The Three Great New Cards Games Broadcasting, Radio, Radio Junior (For Children.) Easy to Learn. A Riot of Clean, Fascinating Fun. The Best Family Game in Years. For Adults, For Children, For Parties. Everybody Likes Them."

A custom card game consisting of a sleeved card box, a 16 page rules booklet, and 48 cards. The cards are marked with the call signs and frequencies of vintage radio stations for twelve cities: WDAF in Kansas City, WCCO in St Paul-Minneapolis, KDKA in East Pittsburgh, WEAF in New York, WFAA in Dallas, WGY in Schnectady, KFI in Los Angeles, KFOA in Seattle, WOO in Philadelphia, KYW in Davenport, Iowa, and KYW in Chicago. Three games are included; Broadcasting (which is an Old Maid variant), RADIO (which is a rummy variant), and Radio Junior (also a rummy variant).

name.value: Dungeons & Dragons Miniatures Game Starter Set

item.description:
Like the first edition of the Dungeons and Dragons Miniatures Game, players pit their warbands against each other on a battle map. Warbands consist of models, each with their own respective characteristics and points values. A typical warband consists of 200 points worth of models, with a maximum model count of 10.

The mechanics has been revised and streamlined, though the overall structure remains. The game has been updated to correspond with the change from 3rd to 4th Ed. Dungeons and Dragons Roleplaying Game.

The three sets released for this game were Dungeons of Dread, Against the Giants and Demonweb. Each is a set of 60 figures, with 8 random figures in each pack, Giants included huge figures. A fourth set, Feywild, was announced but not released. The Starter Set released with Dungeons of Dread, contains a rulebook, five fixed models, their stat cards, counters for tracking damage, a twenty-sided die and two double sided battle maps.

Notable changes in the 2nd Edition:

 Alignment has been simplified. The "Chaotic" and "Lawful" tags have been removed. Only models considered to be absolutely "Good" or "Evil" are given an alignment.
 Warband building is no longer based on alignment, but on "Factions". Each model belongs to one or more of four factions. Every model in a warband must share at least one faction.
 Commanders are gone, replaced by champions. Models no longer make morale checks or rout. Models reduced to half damage are "bloodied." Certain game effects may trigger from this state.




Wizards of the Coast is revising all the stat cards from 11 sets of the first edition of the game to make them compatable with the new version of the game. These stats will be available online in PDFs.

Wizards of the Coast will continue to release miniatures for use with the Dungeons & Dragons Roleplaying game. They have authorized a group of fans to create official stat cards to use these future figures with this minatures game.

Re-implements:

 Dungeons and Dragons Miniatures Game




Home Page: http://www.wizards.com/default.asp?x=dnd/minis

link.value: D&D Miniatures: Orcus , Prince of Undeath

item.description: Cyber Tactics is a Trading Card Game for 2 or more players. Each player is known as a Navigator and they possess decks called the Hard Drive. Navigators draw Data Cards from their Hard Drives and Downloads them into the computerized world of Virtua to engage in combat. The objective is to destroy your opponent's Memory Core before he destroys your own.

The box contains all you need to seek the Eye of the Idol, a fabulous gem of legendary repute:

- a role play adventure taking you through the depths of an unmapped jungle (solo play)
- the rules for a fantasy game set on the island of the idol (for solo or group play)
The game board is built into the box and there is a small cut out area where the dice, counters and rules are stored.

Squelch! is two games in one. They are:

Rain forest adventure board game: Roll the dice and move your counter around the game board, following directions to move yourself and others forward and back.

Treasure hunt: Hunt for specific animals and plants on the board and answer questions about them.

The box contains two dices with ratios on their faces, several coloured sectors of disk; and rings which you can clip the sectors onto. The different proportions used are : 1/2 ; 1/3 ;1/4 ; 1/6 and 1/8.

At his turn, each player throws the two ratio dices and picks up the disks sectors accordingly to the results. Then he tries to arrange those sectors around his rings, in order to form two perfect circles, and wins if he succeeds in this task. Otherwise, the winner is he who has the most rings completes, or else the most sectors.

Three different variants of growing difficulties are proposed, allowing players to make use of different levels of math abilities from adding fractions to basic probabilities.

In Par Out Golf, two armchair golfers from Chico decided to swap traditional golf clubs and balls for wet-erase markers, ink, and a richly illustrated and laminated 18-hole championship game board course. By doing so they made golf portable (think family vacations, road trips and even around the office), accessible and incredibly easy to learn, even for someone who has never stepped foot on a real fairway.

Par Out Golf is challenging, exciting and incredibly unique, playing as inconsistently as the real sport thanks to a twist you'll never "see" coming! It puts you and your family in the middle of the action, competing in stroke play, match play, or one of the many variations that will continue to challenge and entertain round after round.

Best for ages 5 and up and from 1 to 4 players, Par Out Golf is filled with lighthearted competition as players shoot for the lowest score through the 18 stunningly illustrated holes on the course. Game play is easy to learn for the amateur or junior golfer, and still challenging for the pro requiring a strikingly similar level of skill and focus on every shot.

Best of all, this course can be played again and again! A simple wipe with a damp cloth is all it takes to get the greens and fairways ready for another round.

Par Out Golf is played on a set of spiral bound, laminated pages. Special "wet-erase" markers are used so the line is easy to draw, won't smudge, and very easy to erase. The rules are very, very close to the game of golf, complete with sand and water traps, obstacles and slopes. So close is it to "real" golf, you can play each of five classic variations of golf: stroke play, match play, tombstone play, and pro play.

Of the several skills you practice while playing Par Out Golf, a fascinating, and, to any golf player, significant challenge is learning how to visualize your shot. The more observant you are, the more capable you are at remembering the lay of the land, the more effectively you can imagine the exact amount of drive to put on the ball, the better you'll do. This, of course, is the essence of Par Out Golf. Like "real" golf, Par Out Golf challenges both mind and body. If you want to know more about the physical and cognitive aspects of the game, take a look at the thoughtfully written essay: Par Out Science 101 at www.paroutgolf.com.

If you want, you can practice on the Driving Range (on another page) or use the 19th hole (on yet another page) to design your own. You can add your own obstacles, changing the difficulty of each hole, essentially making the game something you can play for-just-about-ever.

Par Out Golf is recommended for 1 to 4 players (it comes with four different wet-erase markers). If you must try before you buy, you can download the first three holes online.

name.value: Dragon's Journey: A Race to Save the Magic

item.description:
Imagine a world where the Magic is dying. Where dragons and wizards are forced into hiding as their numbers dwindle. But the Spirit of Magic gives a final push to save itself and six brightly colored dragon babies are born to powerful parents. All the creatures in Ohadi, a magical land of majestic mountains, rolling rivers and forbidden forests, must work together to teach the babies their dragon skills before the Magic disappears forever.

Be the first dragon to earn all 5 Dragon Skill cards, receive a dragon name, collect each of the 3 treasures from the King's Castle, and return to the cave.

Each player plays a dragon moving around the board collecting various items and avoiding spaces that deter progress.

The Tools of the Trade game introduces children to 32 different occupations and the tools they use as the kids sort pictures into the correct trays.

Includes 4 category boards, 56 colorful tiles, and a red plastic tray.

Smethport Model No. 8301

Designed to be enjoyed by 1 or 2 players Ages 4 - 8.

Players explore the arctic, desert, forest, jungle, ocean, and safari habitats with Zwork, a curious reporter from outer space. As children play the game they improve their vocabulary, thinking skills, and listening skills.

Includes a colorful board, tokens, cards, and question booklet.

(c)1991 Thinking Well

ISBN 1-55999-203-4
